author: @saywhataminreviews676
text:
Good conversation,

As a Black American I want to add a different perspective. The diaspora talk past each other, because we don‚Äôt know each other histories. Black Americans generally don‚Äôt fully know the history of individual countries in the Caribbean and Africa, and Black immigrants generally don‚Äôt understand Black American History or struggles. This leads to frustration amongst both groups. I definitely have heard Black immigrants talk crazy about Black Americans and vice versa. I feel like both groups try to act like the other group is at fault when we are all talking shit about each other.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Absolutely spot on

replies.author: @niyaakbar1098
replies.text: clementmckenzie7041 they‚Äôve been pulling our history out of school for years now and schools are already under funded. Depending on the areas, there‚Äôs a lot of kids who don‚Äôt know much besides the same stories and figures they tell us every year during BHM. my parents took the time to tell me about black history outside of what I learned at school

author: @malikamobley
text: Olay, i really appreciated you perspective on the African diaspora. i remember UK journalist Ash Sarkar said ‚Äúto be racialized is to be treated like a social contaminant‚Äù when you‚Äôre black anywhere, but particularly in the west, you are made to feel like you have no place in the country. immigrant justice is crucial to Black liberation, because until people have the freedom to move, to claim a stake in the place we call home, Black people will never have the power to control our own destinies. Much love, a Black American friend ‚ù§

author: @FloetryFox88
text: A lot black Americans are often made to believe that globally, we're essentially like the "stray dogs" without a home culturally and a so a lot of us begin to romanticize the idea of viewing other black cultures as the only REAL black cultures that we should all try to get closer to. Even though the cultures we have her in America are just as valid culturally.

replies.author: @aboutthat1440
replies.text:
I think it's literally the opposite. We are fully aware that we have culture. By and large. I frankly do NOT see what you are saying much at all.
There's a good bit of push back because so many others in the diaspora come at us with that goofy talking point of we have no culture. 
I am actually surprised you believe what you posted. I simply have never really come across that in person. Even in the media it's an obvious self hater. Usually of the right wing type.

replies.author: @keepingit100lgtv8
replies.text: @qdubtru4522 it's not but it's the most influential and it's not close

replies.author: @FloetryFox88
replies.text: ‚Äã‚Äã@aboutthat1440 see that's the thing, I have personally seen this kind of mentality a lot in different areas. I have known people who have said to my face that black American culture is NOT authentic enough to be considered on the same level as various African, Jamaican etc cultures. Now to be clear, I personally have NEVER subscribed to this kind of thinking, but when you have MFs like Kai Cenat saying "you're just black" along with some others who would rather associate themselves with other versions of black representation, then I would say it's a problem that enough people are buying into. I said what I did because I've actually heard fellow black Americans talking like this before.

replies.author: @FloetryFox88
replies.text: ‚Äã‚Äã@qdubtru4522bro you talking as If I subscribe to the same thinking I was talking about lol I have ACTUALLY seen and heard fellow BLACK Americans talking about how black AMERICAN culture is NOT as legit as the others around the world. I'm literally just speaking on what I've seen folks in my community talk about several times in my life bruh. It's that simple

replies.author: @ADOScirca
replies.text: @aboutthat1440 Why was hidden colors so popular?

replies.author: @ishan5011
replies.text: @aboutthat1440 No we have to acknowledge that a lot of people regardless of diasporic origin feel like they're drawing from an incomplete culture. The start of this conversation is a symptom of that tribalism that does not recognize those feelings and makes an example of someone like Drake who's just doing what literally everyone else is doing. I'm not a Drake fan. but I always got upset with the culture vulture argument cause it's always coming from some better than thou Caribbean who would be quick to tell me of my lack of culture.

replies.text: ‚Äã@aboutthat1440 You really implied the right wing angle in the same post as a "If I don't see it, it must not happen" style sentence.

replies.text:
The people of the Genocidal Holocaust of the Transatlantic Slavery scattered worldwide are the true biblical Israelites written of in the bible. Who was punished by the curses of the Most High for not keeping his laws, statutes and commandments Deuteronomy 28:15-68kJV bible.

Our true heritage and culture has been stripped away from us,  so all that we claim is 
our  culture  today is false. Just a good adaptation of  coping mechanisms within our present situations.of captivity.

Jeremiah 17:4 KJV 
‚ÄúAnd thou, even thyself, shalt discontinue from thine heritage that I gave thee; and I will cause thee to serve thine enemies in the land which thou knowest not: for ye have kindled a fire in mine anger, which shall burn for ever.‚Äù 

Baruch 3:8 Apochrypha KJ bible 
‚ÄúBehold, we are yet this day in our captivity, where thou hast scattered us, for a reproach and a curse, and to be subject to payments, according to all the iniquities of our fathers, which departed from the Lord our God.‚Äù 

Isaiah 51 KJV bible 

22 Thus saith thy Lord the Lord, and thy God that pleadeth the cause of his people, Behold, I have taken out of thine hand the cup of trembling, even the dregs of the cup of my fury; thou shalt no more drink it again:

23 But I will put it into the hand of them that afflict thee; which have said to thy soul, Bow down, that we may go over: and thou hast laid thy body as the ground, and as the street, to them that went over.

Isaiah 51
King James Version
51 Hearken to me, ye that follow after righteousness, ye that seek the Lord: look unto the rock whence ye are hewn, and to the hole of the pit whence ye are digged.

2 Look unto Abraham your father, and unto Sarah that bare you: for I called him alone, and blessed him, and increased him.

3 For the Lord shall comfort Zion: he will comfort all her waste places; and he will make her wilderness like Eden, and her desert like the garden of the Lord; joy and gladness shall be found therein, thanksgiving, and the voice of melody.

4 Hearken unto me, my people; and give ear unto me, O my nation: for a law shall proceed from me, and I will make my judgment to rest for a light of the people.

5 My righteousness is near; my salvation is gone forth, and mine arms shall judge the people; the isles shall wait upon me, and on mine arm shall they trust.

6 Lift up your eyes to the heavens, and look upon the earth beneath: for the heavens shall vanish away like smoke, and the earth shall wax old like a garment, and they that dwell therein shall die in like manner: but my salvation shall be for ever, and my righteousness shall not be abolished.

7 Hearken unto me, ye that know righteousness, the people in whose heart is my law; fear ye not the reproach of men, neither be ye afraid of their revilings.

8 For the moth shall eat them up like a garment, and the worm shall eat them like wool: but my righteousness shall be for ever, and my salvation from generation to generation.

9 Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the Lord; awake, as in the ancient days, in the generations of old. Art thou not it that hath cut Rahab, and wounded the dragon?

10 Art thou not it which hath dried the sea, the waters of the great deep; that hath made the depths of the sea a way for the ransomed to pass over?

11 Therefore the redeemed of the Lord shall return, and come with singing unto Zion; and everlasting joy shall be upon their head: they shall obtain gladness and joy; and sorrow and mourning shall flee away.

Isaiah 52:1 KJV bible 
‚ÄúAwake, awake; put on thy strength, O Zion; put on thy beautiful garments, O Jerusalem, the holy city: for henceforth there shall no more come into thee the uncircumcised and the unclean.‚Äù

author: @danicro1964
text:
Woowee! This one is a doozy! As a American-born child of Grenadian immigrants, who grew up in the ultra-Caribbean enclave that is now known as "Little Caribbean" in Brooklyn and then later in the African-American "Mecca" that is Atlanta I finally feel seen and heard in media! Thank you Olay for hosting this round table, and thank you Foreign for stirring the pot üòÇ 

There's a whole essay/blog post I probably could go write about being caught in the cross-hairs of these unique cultures, but it always comes back to what Olay said: there is nowhere in the world that I will go where I will be perceived as anything other than Black. I think there's a beauty to the different flavors of the African diaspora, but the reality that is the fact that we are a diaspora is due to our collective ancestors' shared subjugation under white supremacy; thus it ONLY benefits us to pursue liberation in a shared manner. There are clearly negative perceptions and experiences many of us have faced (once again, authored by white supremacy), and I really hope that discussions like these help us to heal üñ§

replies.author: @uncensoredreality
replies.text: Literally same! but one thing, we will NEVER call Flatbush ‚ÄúLittle Caribbean‚Äù. Flatbush holds its own weight.

author: @tormentorox1
text:
The fact America is globally hegemonic is an important variable here. Blackness globally is increasingly being filtered through ‚ÄúAmerican Blackness‚Äù and a lot of folks in America don‚Äôt understand that dynamic, or how it affects other people in community. 

The way Blackness is conflated with Black American culture Is something I rarely hear talked about or discussed.

replies.author: @rlchiz
replies.text:
Well, one reason for the conflation is the fact that racial identifier ‚Äúblack‚Äù is central to america. That term did not become a thing until chattel slavery. That‚Äôs one of the main reasons why blackness is tethered to America. 

Secondly, I would blame media. One of Americas biggest export is blackness and it‚Äôs been broadcasted across many airwaves

replies.author: @tormentorox1
replies.text: @callmebyyourname2015 no one said it was.

replies.author: @availanila
replies.text: ‚Äã@rlchiz the identifier "black" started in the Trans-Saharan slave trade where there was the kafir/kufar continent (non-Islamic continent) now known as Africa where they got slaves from since they couldn't enslave Muslimsnand black people started converting later and as a way of protecting from slaves so the assumption that those kufar/kafir were black created the identifier black which gave Africa the name Africa derived from "land of the kafir/kufar" at the time being equal to black.

replies.author: @tormentorox1
replies.text: @NaybaHOODTherapist I agree but it's influence being filtered through and amplified by American hegemony is problematic.

author: @LawMakerBlu
text: Man when I tell you this, THIS is the kind diaspora discourse I love and appreciate. Thank you Olay. Shout outs to all my brothas and sisters from around the globe, especially the ones of us who are trying to dismantle this infighting that has plagued us for far too long.

author: @atongchan8839
text: I love hearing Olay‚Äôs perspective about Immigration. As someone who came to America when I was five and both my parents were part of the Lost Boys and Girls of South Sudan we have had a lot of privilege with the immigration system. My dad came in 2001 to the states as a permanent resident. The rest of us came  in 2005 after being refugees in Kenya. Both my parents were able to get their citizenship  before I turned 18 which made me and my siblings automatically eligible for citizenship. I‚Äôve never had to worry about the immigration process but that doesn‚Äôt negate the reason we were given that opportunity. The war that was going on at the time was horrific and the opportunity to escape was huge for all of us.

author: @adcwilliams994
text: I enjoyed this discussion immensely. Somebody in the comments already said it, but i did come for the slander and i stayed for the Diaspora discussion. It was very welcome, especially because I'm working on a book that I hope can shed more light on the black diaspora as well as other communities. This came at a time when i had recently had a discussion with my uncle about white people and how i would choose to interpret them in my book. As Antionette sang, "whiteness is the problem, not white people,". Another reason I like Olay and friends is because i can study from the way y'all discuss things with each other without invalidating each others experience. Thank you and everyone else for these discussions.

author: @evanrachelhood
text:
‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt that many culture makers, but there are a lot of culture sellers.‚Äù Delaney got my fullest attention when she said that. I didn‚Äôt have the language for the weirdness I felt about the monetization and commodification of blackness, but now I do. 

I‚Äôm seeing more black folks in media, but the connection to community is still missing.

author: @pitpride1220
text:
I love Haiti because of the revolution. So much respect. I've studied Haiti fairly extensively. This conversation made me realize I need to study the broader Caribbean. I'm pretty ignorant of our people there. There is so much to learn throughout the diaspora. 

P.S. I originally came here to represent for slave descendent American black folks. To make sure we were represented well. Very quickly moved on from that. I ended up learning a great deal. Thank you so much.

author: @NicklebagSleezy
text: This is quickly becoming a Sunday staple in my household! Amazing job everyone!

author: @melancholism3553
text:
Thanks a lot for making and sharing this episode. I'm a first generation Indian immigrant and a lot of the topics discussed in this episode honestly hit me like a ton of bricks. I had to stop a couple of times to just cry and process it all. 

I obviously can't speak for or about the black experience, American, Canadian, Carribean or otherwise. But there's a lot of resemblances to the struggles of Indian diaspora, or at the very least my own. 

That sense of feeling like you aren't welcome even in your own home because you get this kind of tag attached to you, and not being accepted in the new land you go to because of your heritage. Ugh, so much stuff to process. 

I often tell people that being an immigrant from India but not belonging to the country we moved to and then finding out the country we came from sees us as pawns to exploit and stereotype as arrogant and rich, it's heartbreaking. 

Sometimes it feels like we have a homeland but no home, you know?

Anyways, sorry for over sharing. Thank you again for making a great episode. I absolutely need to recommend this to others. Stay awesome.

replies.author: @ophionavernus
replies.text:
As first-generation post immigrant myself, from Colombia, I felt a lot of this too.

 There's such a strange struggle with our identity as so much of it is foreigner in my mother's land, but here it's always "but where are you really from?"

author: @BBROXY940

author: @rudetuesday
text: Every time I hear more about Black people's American immigration stories, I am staggered. Each situation is different and so much more difficult than I initially realized. Not a single person had a relatively easy time, and that's a condemnation of the process. If I didn't go out of my way to find out how any of it works (or doesn't work), I probably would never have learned.

replies.author: @nylawoods4572
replies.text:
@TranquilAshes I get where you're coming from but please do not misunderstand me, there are still issues that I think need to be addressed concerning the diaspora and how Black Americans are considered/treated. I was simply giving Olurinatti/Olay kudos for opening up her platform to having diasporic discussions and showing that there are people in the African and Caribbean communities that appreciate, and respect Black American people and our culture. And are willing to discuss the issues that come up as we interact with each other.

Also, There were points I initially wanted to bring up, but it didn't feel relevant to the conversation, more like a topic for another video.

author: @raethereviewer
text: As a Haitian American from South Florida, I really appreciated the representation from Rebecca and the section on Haiti. I did my masters on Caribbean Literature and despite growing up super Haitian in a Haitian community, there was still so much to learn about how much Haiti‚Äôs been screwed over by western powers. I wish the diaspora wars could become more cultural exchange and appreciation and hopefully we get there one day

author: @Chichichichia
text: I hope these types of videos are made more often despite the video description because I learn so much and can relate to some perspectives of immigration but not to this extent and it sheds so much light about the politics specifically for black immigrants. And how it‚Äôs all tied to today‚Äôs politics and to history. Please keep making more of these videos, I learn so much from everyone here please and thank you so much ‚ù§

author: @twistysunshine
text: So im irish american and like. This discussion of black diaspora wars really has me thinking. Because so much of this discussion ("we think the other one has access to something they dont" in regards to culture, the hierarchies discussion about haiti that reminds me of the hierarchies in ireland (the way travellers are treated), the legitimate complaints still not being enough when like. Theres bigger fish to fry) is very familiar to discussion between irish americans and irish people... the way colonization and historical white supremacy is working by walking those same paths in spite of the differences between the Irish and black diaspora. The way no one has ever pointed out that i have seen these similarities between these discussions... one more thing white supremacy does to convince us our experiences are so so different from each other and if we could just keep fragmenting and ignoring each other pretty please (cuz it makes it easier to colonize all of us!) man. Man. This conversation is so important.

author: @britneymiles6246
text: PLEASE KEEP THESE CONVERSATIONS COMING!!  I really appreciate what each of you do and contribute to the conversation.  I hope this type of dialogue leads to identifying further commonalities amongst the diaspora.  It isn't coming from a book, it was casual conversation amongst people, and it is contained within Black perspectives (not just Black Americans).  And, in my opinion, empathy was shown to the all experiences of Blackness.  Thank you for the lesson.

author: @conniekirunda8513
text:
This is such a fascinating conversation. For context, I‚Äôm a first generation South African with Ugandan immigrant parents. My experience mimics first generation Black Americans and immigrants so closely. 

A question I‚Äôve had for the longest time was answered in this conversation when the lack of a diverse representation of Black American culture was being discussed. I finally understand the significance of South Africa having 11 official languages (sign language is the 12 unofficial language). 

From primary school, we are taught there are 11 officially recognised South African cultures and learn about them individually for years. It was incredibly shallow learning when I was that age, yes, and hopefully that‚Äôs changed now, but the point was made. 

It‚Äôs a mandatory aspect of our public (and private) education system to - at the very least - know them by name. And even that shallow investigation to other cultures I had in school was enough to inform my adult life greatly. 

These cultures are seen and taught to be seen from jump. That‚Äôs an incredibly beautiful and powerful thing I took for granted until now.

replies.author: @wandisilesomdyala6834
replies.text:
Fellow South African here. I am Xhosa for context. I would love to hear more on what you mean by this part of your comment "learn about them individually for years. It was incredibly shallow learning when I was that age,"

I ask because I cannot place what that looks like in the school system setting I am knowledgeable about. It sounds like a very specific experience.

author: @bawnfriday
text: this episode was amazing. the only diaspora discussion I've ever seen be productive and start to engage the antagonisms between us. yes olay!

author: @roberth2627
text: Old Head here from the 60's. I get so much from your discussions with all of your Steller guest. Your timely topics are very on  point. I have to admit not that versed on the Hip-Hop scene & all the ends & outs..but still I learn something about  it's  impact still today on Black people of your generation. I really appreciate the  mentioning  of Jazz & the blues ,that was more in currency  in my day by one of your guest.Also about how conservative Black people are in general. The few friends I still have that are alive , I find very conservative & we have many disagreements esp around the LGBTQ community & the Black church .Olay   you remind me so much of a dear friend Diane( She was on the cover of Ebony magazine of June 1966 ) , her father was from Jamacia & she was a trail blazer, who worked with Martin Luther King  when he was in Chicago..I know she would just  LOVE  YOU.She made her  transition  a few years back.. Approaching 80, I learn so much just by being open to the insights you & your guest share.It helps keeps me Young & my Gray brain cells alive..ONE LOVE. !!

author: @jaye5490
text: I really enjoyed this discussion. I hope these types of topics are discussed more on this channel. I'm curious about something. So I'm from the island of Dominica (not DR), and in my country along with many other Caribbean countries we consider ourselves West-Indian people right. Obviously, I'm sure y'all know the history as to why. And lately ive noticed a lot of people on social media go by the term "Caribbean" vs "West Indian". It really baffles me because prior to maybe two years ago I don't think ive ever heard of someone from the Caribbean refer to themselves as "Caribbean." We say "we're from the Caribbean," or "we're West-Indian." Its just a very strange change and ive noticed that it comes from a lot of people who were not born in the Caribbean, but whose parents were born there. Or just random people that have no ties to the Caribbean.

author: @terrelljackson.
text: This video was cool. I think Because Black Americans exist within an American context our identity becomes one of public consumption. Even to be consumed by other Black people. Marquises story was interesting because I think it highlights discomfort for many surrounding boundaries in proximity to Black Americanness. There‚Äôs definitely an idea that it is against the function of the American negro to have boundaries. Which is why people believe that if they are in proximity to us long enough‚Ä¶..that they can become us. A sort of cultural voyeurism if you will. Our cultures interactions are without our consent in most cases.

replies.author: @eightisgr8t
replies.text: I think what facilitates this is the fact that Black Americans are by far the largest black diasporic group in the USA; with deep roots in the country. As such, more often than not, blackness in America is centered around the African American perspective.

replies.author: @terrelljackson.
replies.text: @eightisgr8t well yes as the Black perspective in ever country is centered by that countries prominent version of Blackness. What‚Äôs odd to me is the cultural participation without consent. The experience of the Black American is to just be existing as a Black American only to randomly notice that parts of your identity are being worn like costumes by non-Black Americans. And it‚Äôs not mutual‚Ä¶..this is not the experience of the diaspora at large. I believe it‚Äôs exclusivity is why it‚Äôs not seen as a problem.

replies.author: @eightisgr8t
replies.text: @terrelljackson. How would you know if they‚Äôre doing it without consent though? Some of these 1st, 2nd gens etc. are from communities where they have close ties to AAs that rock with them. Second, to even become famous and/or liked within AA cultural spaces by AAs would suggest a form of consent.

replies.author: @terrelljackson.
replies.text: @eightisgr8t Because being 1st generation does not make you a part of one‚Äôs linage/culture. And Black Americans being tethered to American commerce means the commercialization of our very being is without our consent. Which is why in my first comment I label it as cultural voyeurism. Non-Black Americans will call us uncultured while wearing our very beings. It‚Äôs odd to experience. But expected when the commerce associated with our culture is practiced without our consent.

author: @zemmym.9437
text: Wow, this has been wild hearing just my experience through the mouth of another person. I relate to you so much Olay and that's as a person who is "foreign" in The Bahamas.  Both of my parents are from Guyana but they came over here before I was born, so I was born here. But as you know you don't get citizenship I had to apply for it when I'm 18. It didn't matter tho that I was born here and knew nothing else other than Bahamian culture, I was still "foreign" I was bullied for it and all of that is fine an whatever but really impacted me leaving school. I did what I had to do, I was getting good grades, top of the class but I can't reap any of those benefits because I am "foreign". I'm able to get into college because I have my permanent residence but that expires at 18 so I applied for my citizenship. Long story short it took me 5 years to finally get accepted and in that time I had to pay the foreign rate at the University which is 2 times the normal rate, I could not travel because I didn't have any documents because I was in limbo, I was not be able to get any sort of job to be able to help out with paying, everything was just insanity for 5 years. I have so much disdain for this country that is just unresolved trauma from the immigration system and I'm working on it as I get older, but truly being an immigrant is one of the worst things in my life story.

author: @KMO325
text:
This modern Diaspora Wars debate is sadly older than folks think: A version of this (possibly THE modern version of this debate) was sparked in the late 80s and lasted through the 1990s started by Lucius Outlaw & K. A. Appiah over their wildly-different interpretations of W. E. B. Du Bois‚Äô essay The Conservation of Races. I‚Äôll let others look up the details of the debate, but imagine the Diaspora Wars, but instead of internet commenters it‚Äôs a melee of Africana philosophers going at each other for over a decade.

I think African-American I‚Äôll add this: there is no magical, unifying thing that links a people together. We have a shared history, heritage, cultures, language(s), and tradition within this particular nation-state: that is what makes us African-American as it does for all ethnic groups around the world. 400 years of history and people really still scratching their heads about this. The Souls of Black Folk is public domain‚Äîyou can read it for free and it is as good a primer on African-Americans as any.

And Lies My Teacher Told Me is by James W. Loewen.

text:
Black American here, I never knew there was xenophobia expressed by other black caribbean islanders against Haiti. üòÆ
I love my Haitians and Jamaicans not only because they are a part of my dna makeup but I personally feel that they more than any other black culture understand the Black American struggle more than places like Brazil, the African continent, Black Brits, etc.

author: @gwynnartis
text: The buffer system for immigrant student graduates is basically useless in this current work economy. I just qualified for a two-year visa to find a job (after killing myself to finish my masters), but the requirements to qualify for a basic work visa and the lack of viable job opportunities in my country makes me seriously scared that I won't find something before the two years are up. And I can't move back to my home country - that's just not an option for me. Even then, the country I immigrated to isn't as strict with foreigners as other countries. I couldn't even imagine being an immigrant in the USA, given how draconian their system is. The border system is broken globally but countries like the USA (and UK) are particularly bad. Can relate to Olay saying she had to be a 'special alien' to even have a chance of securing a visa. There's so much bullshit to go through being an immigrant, and if you're any kind of minority/marginalised person on top of that, it's a whole new level of hell because employers won't even bother with you because you might be too 'difficult' to deal with

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: I understand what you‚Äôre going through and the stress you‚Äôre feeling and I‚Äôm praying you get lucky and find a way before the two years are upüíö

replies.author: @gwynnartis
replies.text: @olurinatti Thanks Olay, I appreciate that so much. Seeing somebody like you who's been through it and found ways to navigate the system gives me hope

author: @BeeepMe911
text: The whole "Beyonce has 20 writers" argument is so tired because it willfully ignores how much sampling is involved in her music, and those people are always credited. Teena Marie and her co-writer were given a writing credit on Energy simply for Beyonce saying "ooh la la la." That's it, and boom, two more writers added to the song. It's lame that people that don't understand how sampling/crediting works are always running their mouths lol

Warmed my heart.

author: @deedancer57
text: Thank you so much for this great discussion! I‚Äôm a Drake hater but I kind of understand where he‚Äôs coming from. I grew up in Toronto as a Black Canadian that was not Caribbean and it was tough! Everyone had an island home except me so I wasn‚Äôt considered Black enough and really felt connected to what I saw on TV - Black American culture. So in that way I can see why he picked up that weird accent and has identity issues but don‚Äôt excuse it at all.

author: @jayware4219
text: Just wanted to provide my experience. I feel like being in the south you experience being othered by Yt ppl. For example my dad had a coworker say to a group of coworkers that foreign black ppl work so much harder than American ones. So black communities are purposely being divided. Similar to the model minority stigma. I feel like all minorities need to come together way more than we do now. The isolation is weakening us

author: @EpsilonKeyXIV
text:
Commenting three days after the broadcast, and I don't know if you'll see this...but thank you and Foreign for this episode, Olay! As a first-generation American born of Jamaican immigrants, seeing and experiencing the effects of the diaspora wars is both painful AND exhausting. I've always hated seeing the immigrant generation put down Black Americans and saying things like "they have no culture" was always wild to me, cause at the end of the day the masses are always going to see us as being black...but the fact that fellow Americans have turned around and started saying that Caribbeans and Africans aren't black is just straight WILD to me. Especially considering how many 

I still have a memory of a former friend of mine who once told me that "Jamaicans didn't experience slavery like Black Americans, they were just butlers" like with the strongest of conviction to sort of separate my blackness from his own...and it hurt.

I'm just rambling at this point but I feel like we need to have more of these conversations in general because the division amongst the community helps no one.

author: @mandeanraje2300
text: I love this conversation so much. Especially as a Haitian, loved to see the region solidarity. To add to the American occupation of Haiti, they literally broke in, forced the parliament to remove the law that said that no White man could walk on the land as owner to open Haiti up to CitiBank and its friends, with american soldiers literally surrounding the parliament house. Then, they broke into our treasury and stole the gold reserves to take back to the US for safekeeping. During that same period America bought out the independence debt from france so for over 2 decades, they were the ones collecting the interest. Sh!t's wild.

author: @lerualnaej5917
text: It seems like there's a tension between "Everyone's Blackness is litigated" with the implication that there shouldn't be effort to change that and the frustration against the diaspora wars. How can those two not magnify each other? The litigation will always favor Americans in closest proximity to hegemony over everyone else.
